text: all week david cameron has been under
pressure on his tax affairs yesterday he
faced protesters calling for more
transparency today he feels he's
delivered it the first prime minister in
history to set out so many details about
his income and the tax he pays on it
there's no evidence of tax avoidance
just further proof of his wealth already
knew that David Cameron received 300,000
pounds when his father died in 2010 we
now know he got a further two hundred
thousand pounds from his mother the
following year they were in street
denied suggestions as this was done to
minimize tax liabilities instead it was
to share the inheritance more fairly
between him and his brother and their
leading tax expert says the evidence is
that the Prime Minister has paid
everything that's due I think the main
point from these tax returns that he's
put to bed all the criticism and he's
clearly paid all the tax it was jus and
even beyond that he set the bar very
high for future prime ministers by going
beyond the call of duty the new details
also reveal that the Prime Minister and
his wife Samantha were touched in a
47,000 pounds they got each last year
from renting at their home in London's
Notting Hill we're living in Downing
Street but critics say that David
Cameron still has questions to answer
why is only a four page summary of his
tax affairs been produced and not the
full returns which go to Revenue and
Customs and did any of the money he
received from shares while he was leader
of the Opposition come from other
overseas trusts as well as for his
father's investment company if the Prime
Minister thought that greater
transparency would bring better
headlines he may well be thinking again
this morning in Watson BBC News
